No, Sir; I never spoke to her only to ask if Mrs. May was at home - I had robbed my father before I saw the prisoner; I called at her house one day, when she was not at home - I sent her one letter, but no more; I had given my father's property to a woman of the town, named Lee, before I knew the prisoner - I had visited Lee; I had been in the habit of robbing my father for five months - I was sometimes without any thing in my pocket to give to women; I remember telling the prisoner, shortly before our acquaintance terminated, that I had overheard my father, and mother talking about sending me to sea - I told her that I had got away my boxes, and I said perhaps I might get a situation; I have been to bed with May and with Lee - what I gave them was the price of their prostitution; I used at that time to wear a frock-coat - I told May that I was going on for eighteen years of age, on purpose to deceive her; she wore some of the ornaments I gave her about the street - I remember taking her to the theatre one night; and when we came away I told her she had better not go home, as I thought it not unlikely my father might come - I have taken tea at her house, but I never dined or supped there; I have drank there, we have sent for brandy, and it has been paid for out of the money the things fetched - I had been in custody on a charge of robbing my father before I mentioned this.
COURT. Q. Did she have the silk dress? A. Yes, she did.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. How long had you been in custody before you told this? A. Three or four days; I had been in the New prison, Clerkenwell - I came from there this morning; May had seen me in my father's shop, after I gave her some things - Phillips once said,"I wonder your father does not find it out - if he does I shall get the worst of it;" I thought May looked into my father's shop rather hard the second night I - spoke to her, and I told her not to look in so hard, as I lived there, and she said she would not - Saunders was with her that night; I never told her that my father kept the shop, but his name was over the door; I told the prisoner my name after the Sunday I speak of - she was to pawn the goods I took her, to buy a silk dress; the goods pawned might come to more than 10l. - I took her two pairs of candlesticks.

EDMUND DAVIS
(Police-constable E 86). I took the prisoner on the 31st of August, in High Holborn; I had been to her lodging, in Pettit's-court, Hanway-street - I knew her before, and saw her remove her goods there; I found on her a pair of bracelets, a pair of pearl earrings, a wedding-ring, two caddy-ladles, a buckle, a coral necklace, a coral negligee, and a duplicate for a pair of gold ear-rings; I told her I took her on suspicion of being concerned in the robbery at Mr. Steele's - she said they were the things that young Steele had given her.
Cross-examined. Q. Was any one with her? A. Yes, Phillips.

The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating, that the prosecutor's son had been in the habit of visiting her - that he represented himself as nineteen years of age - and that he had the property from a young man who owed him 10l.
NOT GUILTY .

2417. The said
JANE MAY
,
AMELIA SAUNDERS
, &
CATHERINE PHILLIPS
were indicted for that
they, feloniously did receive, on the 1st of August , of a certain evil disposed person, 3 rings, value 20s.; 2 coral necklaces, value 20s.; 2 pairs of candlesticks, value 3l.; 1 pair of snuffers, value 18s.; 1 snuffer-tray, value 10s.; 36 silver spoons, value 10l.; 1 pair of earrings, value 10s.; 2 coral negligees, value 10s.; 4 pairs of sugar-tongs, value 4s.; 1 broach, value 10s.; 1 pair of bracelets, value 4s., and 1 opera-glass, value 5s., the goods of
Francis Steele
, well knowing the said goods to have been stolen ; against the Statute, &c.
The same evidence was produced as in the former case.
NOT GUILTY .

2415.
AMELIA SAUNDERS
was again indicted for
feloniously receiving, of a certain evil disposed person, on the 5th of August , 1 locket, value 4s.; 2 rings, value 10s.; 1 broach, value 4s., and 1 pair of ear-rings, value 6s., the goods of
Francis Steele
, well knowing the said goods to have been stolen ; against the Statute, &c.
MR. ADOLPHUS declined offering any evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

2416.
CATHERINE PHILLIPS
was again indicted for
feloniously receiving, of a certain evil disposed person, on the 4th of August , 1 pair of sugar-tongs, value 12s.; 1 ring, value 4s.; 2 necklaces, value 1l., and 1 saltspoon, value 1l., the goods of
Francis Steele
, well knowing the said goods to have been stolen ; against the Statute, &c.
No evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .
Sixth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

2417.
WILLIAM WREN
and
THOMAS MARRIOTT
were indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of October , 2 shoes, value 3s. , the goods of
Mary Squires
.

MARY SQUIRES
. I keep a shoe-shop , at Chelsea
. I lost two pairs of shoes on the 8th of October, while I was out.

HANNAH INCE
. I live with my aunt, the prosecutrix. On the 8th of October the shoes were lost, but I did not know who took them; I was told they were taken.

JOSEPH WILKINS
(Police-constable B 100). Between seven and eight o'clock on the 8th of October, Goose and I were coming up the King's-road, and saw the two prisoners near the prosecutrix's house; we watched them -Marriott came from the door with something, which he showed to Wren; it appeared like the shoes: they all walked away - there were four of them together; we followed them to the other side of Sloane-square, and there I caught hold of Marriott - he sprung into the road, and threw something from him; I pursued, but he got into a court - we afterwards found him; this wire and this purse were found on him - the shoes were found thrown down an area.

EDWARD WEATHERLEY
(Police-constable B 20). I went on the beat at nine o'clock; my brother officer told me that something was thrown away - I went the next morning, and found the shoes down the area.

ROBERT GOOSE
(Police-constable R 55). I was with the other officer, and saw Marriott come from the prosecutrix's door; go to Wren, and show him something - they ran off, and we followed them; I found one shoe in another area - I took Wren, but nothing was found on him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Marriott's Defence. I was running home, and this man called Stop thief! I had not been near the shop.

WREN -
GUILTY . Aged 15.

MARRIOTT -
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Whipped and Discharged.

2418.
ROBERT WORLEY
and
JOHN AUSTIN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of September , 12 lbs. of soap, value 5s. , the goods of
Henry Edwards
.

HENRY EDWARDS
. I am a grocer , and live in Great St. James'-street
. On the 17th of September I lost this soap - I did not see it taken; I heard a cry of Stop thief! and run up stairs - I overtook the prisoners about thirty doors from my shop; one run one way and one the other; one was stopped, and the other was taken the next morning - the soap had been hanging on the door-post.

WILLIAM HORSFORD
(Police-serjeant D 6). I saw the prisoners pass the shop twice - they then went and looked into the window; Worley unhung the soap, and gave it to Austin - they run different ways; I pursued Austin up William-street - when I got near him he threw down the soap; I took him turning into George-street -I said, "I want you for taking the soap;" he said,"I did not take it;" I said, "No, but Worley gave it to you;" I went, and took Worley in bed the next morning; I said, "You know what I want you for;" he said, "No, I do not;" I said, "For taking the soap;" he said he took none - I said, "When you were in company with Austin;" he said, "I was not with him."

Worley's Defence. I awoke about half-past nine o'clock, and Austin went to get something for supper - I went out, but could not find him; I then went home to bed, and about two o'clock in the morning the officer came and took me; I am quite innocent.
Austin's Defence. I was going up the street - a man stopped me, and the officer came and took me; he said,"I want you, for having this soap;" I said, "I did not take it, I never saw it."

WORLEY -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

AUSTIN -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined Six Months .

2419.
GEORGE GARDNER
was indicted for that
he, on the 11th of August , did forge a certain request for the delivery of goods , which said forged request for the delivery of goods was as follows - that is to say:
GENTLEMEN, - Please to send by bearer, two reams of demy, at 20s., for Messrs. Cunningham and Salmon.

August 11, 1832. with intent to defraud
John Hodge
and others; against the Statute, &c.
SECOND COUNT, for uttering the same.
THREE OTHER COUNTS, stating his intent to be to defraud other persons.
MR. PHILLIPS conducted the prosecution.

HENRY BLUNT
. I am in the employ of Messrs. Hodge and Co., stationer s. The prisoner came to their shop on the 11th of August, and produced this order; I gave him two reams of paper, worth about 36s., and he went away with them.
COURT. Q. Why did you give him the paper? A. He produced an order, which purported to come from Messrs. Cunningham and Salmon - I believed it to be genuine and good; he said nothing.

JOHN BROWNING
. I am a pawnbroker. The prisoner pawned these two reams of paper with me on the 11th of August.

MORRIS SALMON
. I am one of the firm of Salmon, Cunningham, and Co. The prisoner lived in our employ as porter , and left us in July last - I did not send this order to the prosecutors', nor give any direction; I have no doubt this is forged.

JOHN CUNNINGHAM
. I am in partnership with Mr. Salmon - we are printers. This order is not in my writing; I know nothing of it - there is no other partner.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .
There was another indictment against the prisoner.

2420.
WILLIAM ASKEW
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of October , 1 pair of boots, value 3s. , the goods of
John Skeel
.

JOHN SKEEL
. I lost these boots out of my kitchen in Monmouth-street
on the 10th of October; I was at home, and saw the prisoner come to the place, unhook the boots, double them up, and put them under his arm; he walked a hundred yards, and the Policeman took him - he threw the boots at me, and struck me with them.

EDMUND REA
(Police-constable F 37). I took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I went to Bishopsgate-street to take a gilded frame - I returned up Holborn, and hearda cry of Stop thief! I run, and the Policeman took me-I had not seen the boots.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2421.
WILLIAM COLE ABBOTT
was
indicted for embezzlement .

WILLIAM WARD
. I am a baker . The prisoner was my servant , and had 14s. a week, bread, and beer; it was his duty to account to me, or my daughter for the money he received.

ANN BENGOUGH
. I am a customer to the prosecutor. I paid 1s. to the prisoner on the 15th of October - he did not give me a receipt for it.

JAMES QUINN
. I paid the prisoner at the rate of 2s. a day for three years; I think I paid him last on Monday week, 2s. - I never had a receipt.

EDWARD WILLIAM ADAMS
. I paid the prisoner on the 4th of October 81/2d.; I never had a receipt for it.

THOMAS TOMKINS
(Police-serjeant C 12.) I took the prisoner, and found in his box twenty-five bills - he stated they had been given to him to give to customers, and he acknowledged having embezzled the money.

WILLIAM WARD
. The prisoner never paid me the 1s., not the 81/2d.; he has not accounted to me for this, nor a great deal more; I took him up on Thursday morning, and asked him if they had paid him, and he said they had not - the bread was put down, as not paid for; I did not know of it till he was taken up - he booked the bread, but never gave me the money.

ELIZABETH WARD
. I am the prosecutor's daughter. I booked the prisoner's bread on the 15th of October - he did not give me the 1s.; he booked it as not paid.
Prisoner. It being the first time I was ever in such a place, I hope you will have mercy.
NOT GUILTY .

2422.
JANE BRANCH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of September , 2 sheets, value 8s.; 1 tablecloth, value 2s.; 1 pillow-case, value 4d.; 1 basin, value 3d., and 1 spoon, value 4d. , the goods of
Jane Kingston
.

JANE KINGSTON
. I live in Boston-place, Dorset-square
; the prisoner lodged with me for a fortnight. I missed this property on the 29th of September - she had not left: I said, "What have you done with my sheets and tablecloth?" she gave me the duplicates, and said she would make them good; but she left on Friday.

WILLIAM LANGFORD
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a tablecloth, pawned by a person in the name of
Ann Branch
, but I did not take it in - this is the duplicate which was given for it.

JOHN JAMES
BARTLETT. I am a pawnbroker. I have a sheet, pawned in the name of
Jane Branch
; I do not recollect the prisoner, but this is the duplicate given for it.

THOMAS NEWTON
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a sheet, pawned in the name of
Jane Branch
; I do not know the person - I gave this duplicate for it.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I had some money to make up, and pawned the things.
GUILTY. Aged 42.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Seven Days .

2423.
ABRAHAM BARRETT
and
JAMES WILSON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of October , 1 watch, value 6l., the goods of
Robert Sime
, from his person .

ROBERT SIME
. I am a musician , and live in St. George's-terrace, Commercial-road. On the 16th of October I and my neice were going home, about half-past nine o'clock at night, I was on St. George's-terrace
; I observed some men standing together about the middle of the court, by a lamp - as we were passing them I felt a tug at my watch; the men then ran away - I felt for my watch, and it was gone; I cannot swear to the persons, as I had no suspicion of them.

Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. Where had you been? A. I was out, doing a little business with my wife; I had been to a public-house but a minute before-I was not exactly sober, but I was fit to do any thing; I had drank very little - I might have a pint of beer, or a glass of gin - my wife was quite sober.

CAROLINE PUTT
. I am thirteen years old. I was with the prosecutor, who is my uncle, on St. George's-terrace; I saw Wilson and another man standing in the middle of the terrace; they asked my uncle if it was a throughfare, and then Wilson made a tug at my uncle's watch - there is a gas-light there, and I saw Wilson's person so as to know him again; they ran up the terrace, and across the Commercial-road, and down Essex-street - I followed, and never lost sight of Wilson till I saw him taken by an officer; I cannot swear to the other prisoner.

EMILY TYSON
. I was passing the street, and heard Putt cry Stop thief! I saw the two prisoners running over to Essex-street - Wilson stopped in a cart; Barrett ran on- Wilson said to him, "Don't run, you fool - we are all right now;" a Policeman took Wilson - Barrett ran on, and another officer took him: I had seen the two prisoners walking in company together, between eight and nine o'clock the same evening.
Cross-examined. Q. Where had you seen them? A. In William-street; I had not known them before - they were running fast, but I kept up to them, and did not lose sight of them.

ROBERT CREASEY
(Police-constable H 130). On the night of the 16th of October I was on duty in Essex-street- I saw Wilson and another man, whom I cannot swear to, come running very fast; Wilson seated himself in a truck, and said to the other, "Don't run, you fool - it is all right" I took Wilson, and the other got on; Barrett was taken soon after.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you seen Tyson running? A. Yes, I saw her among the crowd.

GEORGE DUMPER
(Police-constable H 45). I was on duty about half-past nine o'clock that night - I saw three men running; I pursued, and overtook Barrett - I told him he must go with me; I took him towards the cry of Stop thief! and found Wilson in custody - some person recognized him as being one; he was walking at a smart pace, but I believe he had been running - when we got to the watch-house, an officer said, "I saw you and Wilson together in the Commercial-road between eight and nine o'clock this evening;" he said, "I am sure you did not - we were not together this evening, but were in the morning."
Barrett's Defence. I was coming from Whitechapel,and met the officer, but I know nothing at all of it - I have seen Wilson every morning in Petticoat-lane.
Wilson's Defence. I had been to look for a shop, and went under the cart - the officer took me, but I do not know what for.

BARRETT -
GUILTY . Aged 23.

WILSON -
GUILTY . Aged 55.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

2424.
JOHN BUCKLEY
and
JOHN ROBINSON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of October , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
James Helsdon
, from his person .

THOMAS HOBBS
(Police-constable E 85). I saw the two prisoners following the prosecutor into Duncannon-street
, between six and seven o'clock in the evening; I there saw Buckley take the prosecutor's handkerchief, and give it to the other; I pursued Buckley, who ran away; my brother officer took Robinson.
Buckley. Q. Where did you first see us? A. In High-street; you had gone up Oxford-street, down Crown-street, and into St. Martin's-lane.

HENRY BALL
(Police-constable C 31.) I was with Hobbs, and saw Robinson attempt several gentlemen's pockets; when they got to Duncannon-street I saw Buckley take the handkerchief out, and give it to Robinson - I went up and took him; he dropped the handkerchief, which I took up.

JAMES HELSDON
. I am a broker . I had a handkerchief taken from my pocket; I believe this was it - it was a similar pattern, but I cannot swear to the pattern; I knew nothing of it till the officer informed me of it.

BUCKLEY -
GUILTY . Aged 14.

ROBINSON -
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Transported for Seven Years .

2425.
WILLIAM COX
and
JOSEPH TURNER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of October , 5 live tame ducks, price 5s. , the property of
Benjamin Briers
.

BENJAMIN BRIERS. I live at Bedley-heath, South-mimms. On the 16th of October I lost some ducks from my farm at Hadley
- I had seen the prisoners together the same afternoon, before I lost the ducks; I did not know them before - I was going to my farm, and met them about one hundred yards from it, about half-past three o'clock; I did not say any thing to them; they were standing in the road; I went into my fields about three quarters of an hour after, and saw the prisoners again in my field; I went towards them - they got over the hedge into another field: I then hallooed to them, and saw Cox had a bundle- they began to run away; I followed - Cox dropped the bundle; I took it up, and it contained five ducks, which I believe to be mine - they were killed, and quite warm.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. When had you seen the ducks? A. I had not seen them that day; there is a near way across my fields to Barnet.
Cross-examined by MR. DONNE. Q. Do you know Mr. Morgan? A. No; I know that Turner lives at Barnet now, but I did not then.

SAMUEL COOKMAN
. I live with MR. Briers. I know these ducks; they were safe on the 10th of October, in the evening, when I left home - I was out when they were lost.

MARK WALCH
. On the 16th of October I received information of this - I went and took Turner at his father's house; and Cox at Holloway, the next morning; Turner said he was very sorry, but he did not kill the ducks-Cox said poverty drove him to it, and he had only had one penny roll for two days, which I believe to be true; he has a wife and two children, and has been hard working and industrious.

THOMAS AUSTIN
. I went with Walch, and took Cox; he has been out of work, and said he should not have done it but for want.
TURNER - GUILTY. Aged 28.
COX - GUILTY. Aged 21.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Two Months .

2426.
FRANCES CHAPMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of October , 1 gown skirt, value 7s. , the goods of
Mary Grove
.

MARY GROVE
. I am a widow , and live in Richmond-street, Bartholomew-square
- the prisoner came to clean, and help me wash. On the 2nd of October I missed a gown-skirt; I asked her several times what she had done with it, and she said she had taken it to a dress-maker's, in Old-street, but refused to tell me the number, and would not go with me.

CHARLES VORLEY
. I am a pawnbroker, in Old-street. I have a gown skirt, pawned on the 2nd of October, by the prisoner.

THOMAS MIDDLETON
(Police-constable C 196.) The prisoner was given into my custody - the prosecutrix said if she would tell me where it was she would not give her into custody; she told before the Magistrate, and I got it.
Prisoner's Defence. She promised me the skirt, and told me to take it home, and make it up - I thought to get it out, but had not the money.
NOT GUILTY .

2427.
JOHN CARROLL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of September , 6 lbs. of butter, value 5s. , the goods of
George Partridge
.

GEORGIANA PARTRIDGE
. My brother George lives in Bunhill-row
. On the 26th of September, about two o'clock in the day, the prisoner entered the shop, and inquired if Mr. Partridge was in; I said No - he said he wanted half a dozen pounds of butter, for Mr. Crick; I gave it to him, knowing Mr. Crick to be a customer; but as I suspected him, I sent our lad after him, to inquire of Mr. Crick - I had never seen him before, but I am sure he is the person; he was taken the next day.

HENRY TRAVER CRICK
. I know nothing of the prisoner; I never sent him, nor any one that day - I never saw him till he was in custody.
Prisoner's Defence. A young man met me close by the house, and asked if I would go for half a dozen pounds of butter, for Mr. Crick - which I did, and brought it to him.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Confined One Month .

2428.
JOSEPH COWEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of October , 21/4 yards of cloth, value 2l. , the goods of
Richard Culverwell
.

RICHARD CULVERWELL. I am a tailor , and live in Great Marylebone-street
. I lost this piece of cloth from my shop - I saw the prisoner, who was a stranger, turning out of my shop; I had not left my cutting-board five minutes; the prisoner was quite a stranger - I did not see him come in; I called to him, but he would not stop - I left my chair, and followed him; I called to him, and then he would not stop - I walked after him; when he got about thirty yards he began to run; I called Stop thief! a butterman put his basket down, and tried to stop him, but could not - he turned Bulstrode-street; I was close after him, and saw him throw down the cloth, with the intention of throwing it down an area, but he could not - I took it up, the Policeman brought him back, and took the cloth.

JAMES FORD
(Police-constable E 9). I took the prisoner running, and have the cloth.
MR. CULVERWELL. This is the cloth - I had placed it on the cutting-board just before I left it, to get my breakfast.
GUILTY. Aged 21.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Six Weeks .

2429.
JOHN DWYER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of October , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
George Rennell
from his person .

GEORGE RENNELL
. I am a butler . I was in Wilderness-row
on the 9th of October, at half-past eight o'clock in the evening; I did not feel my handkerchief taken, but the Policeman tapped me on the shoulder - I looked round, and saw my handkerchief on the ground, and the prisoner in custody.

JOHN SMITH
(Police-constable G 205). I was in a shop and saw the prisoner taking this handkerchief; I followed him, and he drew it quite out - I took him, and he dropped it.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 17.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Six Weeks .

2430.
HENRY DAWSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of October , 23 yards of merino, value 1l. 4s. , the goods of
Uriah Macey
.

JOHN ROBERT HOLMES
. I am apprentice to Mr.
Uriah Macey
, linen-draper , Great Titchbourne-street
. On the 3rd of October, about half-past eight o'clock, I heard a noise in the shop, that drew my attention to the door; I went out, and saw the prisoner with a piece of merino under his arm- I followed him up Foley-place; when I got within a few yards of him, he threw it down; I picked it up, and gave an alarm - Powell followed and took him; I am sure he is the person - it was taken from within the shop, near the door.

WILLIAM POWELL
. I was standing in my shop in Foley-place, and heard a cry of Stop thief! I looked out and saw the prisoner running away, and Holmes pursuing him; I saw him throw down the merino - I pursued, and brought him back.

WILLIAM MARSHALL
(Police-constable E 31). I took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to)

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Confined Six Months .

2431.
WATTS EDWARDS
and
GEORGE ROGERS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of October , 1 basket, value 1s., and 40 eggs, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
John Brown
.

MICHAEL SCANTLING
(Police-constable G 118). I saw the prisoner in Radnor-street, City-road, on the 15th of October; I saw Edwards running, and carrying this basket, which was covered with this apron - Rogers was behind him, but had nothing; it was between five and six hundred yards from the prosecutor's - I took Edwards, and Lapthorn took Rogers; I found the owner of the property.

JOHN LAPTHORN
(Police-constable C 102). I saw the prisoners running together; I heard Edwards say to Rogers "Come along" - we run after them; Rogers run off, I followed and took him.

MARGARET BROWN
. I am the wife of John Brown. I lost a basket with eggs; as near as I can tell this is it-I missed it from my window, which was open, when the officer asked me; I saw a boy in the evening looking through the window - I cannot tell if it was one of the prisoners.
Edwards put in a written defence stating that they had met a man who had employed them to carry the basket; he received a good character.

EDWARDS -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Confined One Month .

ROGERS -
NOT GUILTY .

2432.
HENRIETTA MARIA FRANKLIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of October , 1 handkerchief, value 5s., the goods of
Joseph Usher Still
, from his person .

JOSEPH USHER STILL
. I attend on insane persons , and live in Derby-row, Kingsland. On the 12th of October, between two and three o'clock in the morning, I was going home - I had been out with some friends, and drank a little, but nothing of any consequence; I fell in with the prisoner in Kingsland-road - I walked up Old-street-road
with her- I sat down and took her on my knee; when she had been with me a quarter of an hour, she left me suddenly-I missed my handkerchief in about twenty minutes from my right hand coat pocket; I had not given her any money, nor did she ask me for any - I had seen her once before, but was not acquainted with her; I did not give her the handkerchief.

RICHARD HUNT
(Police-constable H 70). I took the prisoner and found the handkerchief partly in her pocket; she at first denied having it.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. He promised to give me something and did not.
NOT GUILTY .
OLD COURT. WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 24.
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

2433.
WILLIAM WOOD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of October , 9 shillings, and 1 penny , the monies of
John Tucker
.

CHARLOTTE TUCKER
. I am the wife of
Joseph Tucker
; we keep a coal-shed in Cumberland-street, Middlesexhospital
. The prisoner came there in the afternoon of the 12th of October, between three and four o'clock, and asked me to send 1/2 cwt. of coals, and 1d. worth of wood,with change for half a sovereign, to No. 11, Tottenham-street - he went away, returned, complained that I had not sent them, and said he would wait and go with the boy; I gave the boy the coals with 9s. 1d. - I told him to give him the change, and bring me back the halfsovereign.

JOSEPH TUCKER
. My mother sent me with the coals, and 9s. 1d. - I went with the prisoner nearly to Tottenham-court-road; he then asked for the change, and said he would give me the half-sovereign - I gave him the change, which I would not have done, but he said he would give me the half-sovereign, and he ran away with it - I put the coals down, ran after him, calling Stop thief! and he was taken.
Prisoner. I did not walk fast - he put it into my hand. Witness. He asked me for it.

RALPH JACOBS
. I live in Church-street, Shoreditch. I was in Tottenham-court-road - the prisoner run by me; Tucker called Stop thief! - I saw the prisoner stopped, and pushed down; he got up and ran again, but was secured and searched, but the money not found; I at last said I would strip him but what I would find it - he said"Well, if you will forgive me, I will give you the money;" he had then got 9s. 1d. in his hand.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Confined Three Months .

2434.
WILLIAM WALLACE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of September , 1 coat, value 5s. , the goods of
Charles Thomas Charlwood
.

CHARLES THOMAS CHARLWOOD
. On the 29th of September I left my great coat in a cart, in Tavistock-place, Covent-garden
; I lost it, and afterwards saw it in Norton's hands - this is it.

JOSEPH NORTON
(Police-constable F 44). On the 29th of September, about half-past five o'clock in the morning, I stopped the prisoner in Little Russell-street, with this coat under his arm - he said it was his own.
Prisoner's Defence. I was in Covent-garden, and saw the coat on the ground, at the horse's heels.

CHARLES THOMAS
CHARLWOOD. It could not have fallen at the horse's heels; it was in the body of a large cart.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2435.
MARY WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing on the 3rd of October , 1 pair of boots, value 30s.; 1 waistcoat, value 10s., and 2 handkerchiefs, value 3s. , the goods of
Benjamin Wurr
.

BENJAMIN WURR
. I live at Chelsea, and work at a stable . I met the prisoner on the 2nd of October, I went with her to George-street, St. Giles'
, and went to bed with her - when I awoke in the morning she was gone; I missed my boots, waistcoat, and two handkerchiefs.
Prisoner. He told me to pawn them for what he had promised me, as he had but 21/2d. Witness I did not; she took them while I was asleep - I do not know whether she lodged there.

WILLIAM WOODMAN
(Police-constable F 9). On the 23rd of October, between five and six o'clock in the morning, I stopped the prisoner in Drury-lane with a bundle, containing a pair of boots, a waistcoat, and handkerchief - the other handkerchief was tied round her thigh; she said they were her own, and that she had pawned a ring to get them out of pawn.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. He gave me them to pawn, and said William should fetch them back; I have known him two years.

BENJAMIN WURR
. I knew her two years ago, when she lived at the White Hart, Holborn - she never pawned any thing for me; I never lived with her - I was sober.

GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Before Mr. Recorder.

2436.
JAMES YOUNG
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of October , 1 painting, value 2l., and 1 pictureframe, value 15s. , the goods of
Alfred Weaver
.

JAMES HORNING
. I am shopman to Alfred Weaver, carver and gilder , Brompton-row, Knightsbridge
. On the 16th of October, between eight and nine o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoner going out of the shop with this painting in his hand - the moment he saw me he attempted to put it on the table, but it fell down; he ran out - I pursued him about fifty yards, calling Stop thief! and he was stopped - the shop door was open,

JACOB McCARTHY
. I am a Policeman. I saw the prisoner running, and assisted in securing him; as soon as he heard a cry of Stop thief! and the people running after him, so that he could not get away, he stopped.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he had merely taken the painting up to look at.

JAMES HORNING
. I was in the workshop, under the shop where the painting hung - I heard somebody over head, ran up, and saw him going out with it; he was on the step of the door, but on seeing me he put it down.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Confined One Month .

2437.
WILLIAM CHAPMAN
and
JAMES HARRIS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of October , 1 watch, value 25s., and 1 key, value 1s. , the goods of
Barbara Folkard
.

BARBARA FOLKARD
. I am a widow , and keep a shop in William-street, Manchester-square
. On the 18th of October, about eight o'clock in the morning, I saw Harris in my shop - he asked to look at an old tea-saucer; he then looked at something else - I was engaged with him about ten minutes, and he left without buying any thing - my watch hung on the parlour mantel-piece; I do not know whether the private door was open, but if it was, any body could get into the parlour - a neighbour came over and gave me information; I went into the parlour, and the watch was gone - Harris had left then, and in about an hour I saw the prisoners in custody with it - they were strangers.
Harris. Q. Are you sure it was I who came to your shop? A. He is the man.

THOMAS COCHRAN
. I am a saddler, and live nearly opposite Folkard; about ten minutes to eight o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoners lurking about the street, in company together - I watched them; one of them looked through the key-hole of the private door; they then went on down the street together, and returned; the prosecutrix was sweeping the front of hershop; as they passed, one pushed the other, as if to say, go in at the private door, which was then open; they went on, then came back, and the door was put too - I do not know whether it was shut; Chapman looked through the key-hole, then opened the door, and went in; Harris went in at the shop door; I ran down the street to look for a Policeman, but could not find one, and on returning, I told my employer what I had seen; Chapman came out at the private door, and Harris at the shop door; my employer went over, and told the prosecutrix; the prosecutrix's son and I went after them - we could not find them; we met a Policeman, and described them - he afterwards took them; I am certain of them both - the watch was found on Chapman.

Harris. Q. Did you see me with Chapman after I came out? A. Chapman stopped and spoke to two others at the corner, and Harris went by, and did not speak to him; but they were in company together when we took them.

WILLIAM HOOKER
. I am a Policeman. I received information, and went to Lisson-grove, about a mile from the house, and saw the prisoners going along; Cochran pointed them out - I ran; Harris turned round, saw me, and stopped as if for a necessary purpose; I told Cochran to take him; I followed, and took Chapman - I saw the watch-key in his mouth, and caught hold of it - we struggled; I forced his mouth open, and believe he must have swallowed it; I saw another watch-key hanging from his pocket - I caught hold of it; he said, "It is mine, what do you want with it?" I found the watch in that pocket, and in Harris's pocket I found a skeleton and a latch-key; Harris said, "I know nothing of it, I have not been with him."(Property produced and sworn to).
Chapman's Defence. About five minutes before I was taken, I met Harris, and asked him to go across the fields with me - he did not know what I had in my pocket.

Harris' Defence. I unfortunately met Chapman about five minutes before; I had not seen him all the morning before; he asked me to cross the fields with him on an errand; I turned and saw two Policemen, but did not think they were after me, and stopped.

CHAPMAN -
GUILTY . Aged 20.

HARRIS -
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

2438.
EDWARD FOLEY
and
WILLIAM BRIDGE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of October , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
Charles Warton
, from his person .

CHARLES WARTON. I am an auctioneer , and live in Threadneedle-street. On the 5th of October, about ten o'clock in the morning, I was in New-street, Covent-garden
, and had my handkerchief in my pocket; Ruffy gave me information, and I missed it - I saw Bridge there, but not Foley.

JOHN RUFFY
. I am an oilman, and live in James-street, Covent-garden. I was in New-street, and saw the prisoners together; my attention was attracted by Foley beckoning to a boy behind him - I watched, and saw Bridge take a handkerchief from the prosecutor's pocket, and put it behind him; Foley was alongside him, and could not help seeing it - I informed the prosecutor, and then pursued; they took different directions - Bridge dropped the handkerchief in the middle of the road, and was taken directly after by the Policeman, who took it up- Foley was brought to the station in about half an hour; I had not seen him do any thing.

THOMAS POCOCK
. I am a Policeman. I heard a cry of Stop thief! and saw Bridge running; he put his hand into his bosom, and threw the handkerchief away; I took it up and secured him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Foley's Defence. I was going to the workhouse for my mother's money, and had the ticket in my hand.

THOMAS POCOCK
. He had the ticket in his pocket, and said as he does now.
Bridge's Defence. I met this boy, and asked where he was going; I was by the gentleman, but never touched him.

BRIDGE -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

FOLEY -
NOT GUILTY .

2439.
HENRY BARR
and
THOMAS SMITH
were indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of October , 2 pistols, value 18s. , the goods of
Abraham Edmund Reynolds
.

RICHARD PEACHY
. I am servant to
Abraham Edmund Reynolds
, of Mile-end-road
- these pistols were on a stall-board, in the street; they were taken between eleven and twelve o'clock - I found them at the station.

JOHN GAMBLE
. I am a bottle-merchant, and live in Globe-road. On the 18th of October I was in my cart, in Mile-end-road, and saw Smith take these pistols off Reynolds' board, which was about three yards from the house- he gave them to Barr; I jumped out of my cart, and informed the prosecutor - we pursued, and Smith was taken in the fields; Barr was taken by a Policeman - they were both taken within ten minutes.

THOMAS MARSHALL
. I am a Policeman. I apprehended Barr, with the two pistols wrapped in his apron.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Barr's Defence. I happened to meet this young gentleman - he snatched the pistols off the board, and gave them to me.

BARR -
GUILTY . Aged 19.

SMITH -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Confined One Year .

2440.
JULIA DWYER
and
ESTHER PAGE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of October , 2 sheets, value 12s., the goods of
William Matthias Spooner
; and 1 gown, value 5s., the goods of
Eliza Smith
.

WILLIAM MATTHIAS SPOONER
. I live in Bath-place, New-road
. On Wednesday night, the 3rd of October, when I went to bed, my house was all safe - Smith , my servant, alarmed me at seven o'clock in the morning, and property amounting to 4l. or 5l. was stolen; the sheets had been washed and laid in a basket in the kitchen, with the other linen - I knew nothing of the prisoners; I went down on hearing the alarm, and found the premises had been forcibly entered, the kitchen in confusion, the linen tumbled about, and the drawers and every placerifled - I went and gave information at the station-house, and was informed the prisoners had been stopped in another district; and at eleven o'clock I saw my property at the office.

ELIZA SMITH
. I am in the prosecutor's employ. I got up at seven o'clock in the morning, and on opening the parlour shutters saw a shirt and tablecloth in the garden - they were in the kitchen the night before, in a basket of linen ready for the mangle; I missed two sheets and my gown, which I found at the office that morning - two doors had been forced open, the frame and all forced in.(Property produced and sworn to.)

DAVID LAING
. I am a Policeman. I stopped the prisoners at a quarter to one o'clock in the morning, walking arm-in-arm, in Fitzroy-street, about one hundred yards from the prosecutor's - I asked twice what they had got; Dwyer said, "I have got some things;" I said, "What things?" she said, "Some things which belong to the other girl's mother;" I opened her apron, and found two damp sheets, and on Page I found two gowns: I found no housebreaking implements on them.
Dwyer's Defence. I am an unfortunate girl, and knew this girl by buying oysters of her; we walked together-I saw this parcel, and took it up.
Page's Defence. I met her - she said she was could and hungry; I got her some victuals, and, as we walked along, picked the bundle up.
Page received a good character.

DWYER -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

PAGE -
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Confined Three Months .

2441.
JOSEPH HOSKINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of October
, 13 forks, value 7s., and 12 knives, value 7s., the goods of
John Abrahams
; and
JAMES LOCK
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen .

ALICE ABRAHAMS
. I am the wife of
Isaac Abrahams
, a jeweller and diamond merchant; he is a lunatic - I live with my father, in Vinegar-yard, Drury-lane
. Hoskins was my father's servant , and lived in the house - this property belonged to my husband; I saw the knives and forks safe about ten days before he left, which he did very late on the night of the 10th of October, without notice, and in a day or two missed these things - I saw them at the office, when the prisoners were taken - when Hoskins was taken he said he was not sorry he was taken, and could tell me where the property was; in consequence of what he said Lock was taken.

BENJAMIN KEY
. I am an oil and colourman. Last Saturday week, at night, Lock came to my shop, and offered me eleven knives and twelve forks for sale, with a carving knife and fork - he asked 10s. for them, which I gave him; he was in the habit of coming backwards and forwards - I have known him thirteen years, and believed him particularly honest; he kept a marine-store shop in White Hart-yard.

GEORGE MAY
. I am a Policeman. I apprehended Lock; he said he had bought some knives and forks of Hoskins, and gave him 2s. 6d. and the duplicate of a silk handkerchief for them. I took him to the prosecutor's and he said the same there.
Lock. They were not in the state they are now - I had a deal of trouble to clean them; they were in a shocking state.

ALICE ABRAHAMS
. I have had them a long time, but they were not much used; they were perfectly clean when taken - when Lock was brought to our house, he said, rather than have any bother he would pay for them - I value them at 14s.
Lock's Defence. He came to my shop, and asked 4s. for them, which I gave him; I might be out of my judgment, but I never assoicated with thieves.

HOSKINS -
GUILTY - Aged 19.

LOCK -
NOT GUILTY .

2442. JOSEPH HOSKINS was again indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of October
, 1 watch, value 2l.; 1 watchguard, value 10s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 10s.; and 6 handkerchiefs, value 6s.; the goods of
Emanuel Moses
, his master ; and
JOHN SMITH, alias BAKER
, was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen .

EMANUEL MOSES
. I keep the Black Lion, Vinegaryard, Drury-lane
. Hoskins was in my employ; he left on Wednesday, the 10th of October, a little before twelve o'clock at night; he had half a crown a week; and had been paid on the Monday; I sent my wife up stairs when we missed him, and the watch and other things were missing - I had seen the watch an hour before - I saw the shoes last Saturday at Queen-square, where Smith was in custody - my shoes are patent ones, such as cannot be found in London.

ALICE ABRAHAMS
. I heard the prisoner going up stairs about eleven o'clock at night - I was in bed on the second-floor, and said, "Joe, is that you?" he said Yes - I heard him open the door of the room this property was in; and as he came down, seeing a light through the crack of the door, I said, "How is it you have a light?" as we never allow one - he said he had been to take some things up stairs, and in about an hour I heard of the robbery - when Hoskins was taken, he said he gave the property to Baker to sell, in Field-lane - I had seen the watch that evening, and had it in my hand - six handkerchiefs were missing from a lumber-room, opposite the room the watch was in.

ROSINA JONES
. On the Wednesday night Hoskins left his place, I came up Drury-lane between twelve and one o'clock, and saw the two prisoners in company; having drank with Baker, before I said, "Will you give me something to drink?" he said, "If you will come with us, you shall have something" - I said, "Where are you going?" he said, "To Field-lane, to sell two handkerchiefs" - they each had a handkerchief on their necks, and when they got to Field-lane, they took them off their necks - Baker went in, and said he had sold the handkerchiefs for 3s.: they then went to sleep in St. Giles' - I slept with a female in the opposite room - I had never seen Hoskins before, but had known Baker about twelve months - I am an unfortunate girl; I saw a silver watch with an engine-turned case, and a guard to it, in Baker's possession, that night; next morning they came into the room where we were sleeping- Hoskins asked me to go and get them some breakfast, which I did, and we all four breakfasted together - Hoskins took the watch from Baker at breakfast time, and returned it again; and between ten and eleven o'clock theywent to West-street, Smithfield - Hoskins gave the watch to Baker in Smithfield; he put it round his neck, and in West-street he took it and put it into his pocket; he went into a house on the left hand side, came out, and said he had sold it for 1l. 4s. 6d. - he gave Hoskins 12s. and the odd 6d. was spent in drink - Baker then said he was going to see somebody in Newgate; we stopped opposite the door; he said he must go and get something to take in to him; he left us; I did not see him again, but on Friday night I saw Baker at the White Hart, and on Sunday evening I saw Hoskins - I saw nothing of him till he was taken up; a Policeman came to me, and I told him what I knew.

JOHN SELLS
. I am in the employ of Mr. Turner, pawnbroker, Brydges-street, Covent-garden. I have a pair of shoes, pawned on the 10th of October, between two and three o'clock, in the name of John Moseley, for 2s. 6d.; I do not know who by.

GEORGE MAY
. I am a Policeman. I apprehended Hoskins on the 17th of September - he said he was not sorry he was taken; I heard him tell a young man at Queen-square that he had pawned the shoes at Turner's - I heard nothing about the watch; I took Baker at the White Hart, White Horse-yard - I said,"Is your name Baker?" he said, "No, it is Smith;" and denied all knowledge of Hoskins.
ALICE ABRAHAM. I never saw Hoskins with a watch of his own - he was very poor.

HOSKINS -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

SMITH -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

2443.
HARRIET EVANS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of October , 1 pair of shoes, value 4s. 6d. , the goods of
Thomas Perean Morgan
.

THOMAS PEREAN MORGAN
. I live in Chesterfield-place, New-road
. On the 5th of October, about one o'clock, I missed a pair of new shoes from under my window; I went to the first pawnbroker's shop in the same place, and found the prisoner at the counter, with them in her hand - she said they were hers, and she had given a man outside 1s. for them; I asked if she could point him out; she pointed to a man, and when I got up to him she said it was not him, it was another farther on; and when we got to him, she said it was not him - I gave a man in charge, who she said she had them from; the Magistrate discharged him.

CHARLES MUMFORD
. I took the prisoner into custody.
Prisoner's Defence. The man asked me to buy them; they would not fit, and he asked me to pawn them.

GUILTY . Aged 27. -
Confined One Month .

2444.
WILLIAM FAWCITT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of October , 1 picture, framed and glazed, value 5s. , the goods of
John Pratt
.

ELIZABETH PRATT
. I am the wife of
John Pratt
, a fringe-maker , in Exeter-street, Portland-market
. On the 17th of October this picture was taken; I had seen it safe in the parlour the day before - the shop door is open in business hours; I never saw the prisoner in the shop - I believe he was in distress.

HENRY BYFIELD
. I am shopman to Mr. Gideon, pawnbroker, Stafford-street, Lisson-grove. On the 18th of October I was informed this portrait and frame were stolen, and shortly after the prisoner came and offered it in pledge; I detained him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I bought it.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Confined Two Months .

2445.
WILLIAM JACOBS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of October , 2 shillings, the monies of
John Cross
, from his person .

JOHN CROSS
. I live in Boswell-court, Queen-square
; the prisoner and I lived in the same room, and slept together for three months. On the 18th of October, having suspicion that he was robbing me, I stopped out, and did not go home till six o'clock in the morning; I was employed at some stables - I was quite sober; I put my waistcoat on a chair at the foot of the bed; when he got up, I pretended to be asleep; I saw him take my waistcoat up, and put it down again, and directly he was gone, I missed two shillings; I went out after him - I got a Policeman, and gave him into custody; he denied it; nobody else slept in the room; his clothes were not on the same chair as mine, that I observed.

Prisoner. He came home in liquor; I helped him off with his great coat. Witness. I feigned to be drunk, wishing to find who was the thief - he denied it, but when he got to the station he said he found the two shillings on the carpet; it was day-light; my waistcoat had sleeves, but his had not.

CHARLES WELLDING
. I am a Policeman. The prosecutor charged the prisoner with this; I told him to produce his money; he produced two half-crowns and some shillings; among them were two marked shillings, which Cross claimed; the prisoner denied it at first, but said at the station that he found them on the carpet.

JOHN CROSS
. These shillings are mine - I marked them overnight.

GUILTY . Aged 32. -
Confined Six Months .

2446.
JOHN KNIGHT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of October , 1 tunic value, 2s.; 1 waistcoat, value 3s.; 1 scarf, value 7s., and 2 belts, value 2s., the goods of
William Henry Williams
; 3 jackets, value 3s.: 1 waistcoat, value 1s., and 1 shirt, value 1s., the goods of
Richard Hughes
; and 1 dressing-case, value 2s., and 1 coat, value 18s., the goods of
Samuel Johnson
.

JEREMIAH MURPHY
. I am a labourer, and live in Goswell-street; I am a night watchman at Sadler's-wells
. On the 14th of October I went there about ten minutes before my usual time - I put my hand to the back door, which leads into Arlington-street
, and it flew open; I found the prisoner inside, with a bundle in his hand; I laid hold of him - he immediately dropped it; it contained the articles stated in the indictment; he was quite a stranger.

JOHN ROBINSON
. I am a Policeman. I received the prisoner in charge; I think I had seen him lurking about the theatre at different times.

FRANCIS CAPRANI
. I was engaged at Sadler's-wells; some things in this bundle belong to Mr. Williams and others: there are four proprietor s - the things were kept in the dressing-room.
SAMUEL JOHNSON. I am a performer . This dressing-case and coat are mine; I have seen all these other things worn by the different performers.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was in distress, and went to the theatre to sleep all night - I found the things tied in the bundle.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2447.
JOSEPH LEARY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of September , 1 piece of iron, called a poppet-head, value 13s.; 1 collar and mandle, value 13s.; 2 rest-screws, value 10s.; 2 tops and boxes, value 5s., and 1 iron cramp, value 12s. , the goods of
William Bradick
.
WILLIAM BRADICK. I am a turner and bedsteadmaker ; the prisoner was eighteen months in my employ -I was from home when these things were taken.

Prisoner. Q. Did you pay me any wages on Saturday night? A. Every Saturday; I have his signature in my book up to the last fortnight that he worked for me - when I was absent my wife has overpaid him; I never knew him pawn my property.

JAMES ALDOUS
. I am a pawnbroker, in Berwick-street. On the 7th of September the prisoner pawned a cramp, for 4s.

JOHN NEEDS
. I am shopman to Mr. Chaffers, of Greek-street, Soho. I have a turner's rest and screw, pawned on the 18th of September, in the name of John Williams; I believe by the prisoner.

JOHN REARDON
. I live in High-street, Bloomsbury. I have a box and tap, pawned on the 4th of April, but not in my presence.

WILLIAM CLARK
. I am shopman to Mr. Jones, High Holborn. I have a collar and mandle, pawned for 4s. - the prisoner does not appear to be the person.

GEORGE HOBBS
. I am a Policeman. I apprehended the prisoner on the 5th of October, at work at another shop - I asked where he kept his duplicates; he said he had but one, and that he gave to the prosecutor's wife - it was for the collar and mandle.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. On the day he got my signature to the book, he got a stranger to witness it; after I signed it I brought home work, which he cannot deny; he said,"I have your signature, and you are paid;" I said, "I am not paid for these draw-knots;" he said I should be paid another time - I often had goods given me to pledge, to raise money to pay the men.

WILLIAM BRADICK. I never let him go without the whole of his money; if I was short, I let it go, perhaps, a week - I was in trouble about an action, and the person I left in charge of my business, took his signature; I never asked him for it myself - he did not turn sixteen dozen of draw-knots for me.

JOHN HILL
. I am a turner, and live in New Compton-street. The prisoner occasionally worked for me; I lent Bradick a rest, which I never could get back, and this is it - it has been in my uncle's possession fifty years; and, to tell you the truth, all these tools are mine, for I gave Bradick the money to pay for them - I only claim the rest- I consider he will take a false oath.

CHARLES APPLEYARD
. I am a porter. I have been in Bradick's employ nine months; he authorized the prisoner to pawn the tools on account of the non-payment of his money, and he owes me money for labour - I have heard him tell the prisoner to pledge his tools, and offer him money afterwards to redeem them; he was taken to the Marshalsea-prison, and owes me 12s.; he sent the prisoner to pawn a top and box-rests, and things- I never heard him authorize the prisoner to pledge, but he knew it was done, and gave him money to redeem them.

- FORD. I am a bedstead-maker. The prosecutor called at my shop between nine and ten months ago, and asked if I had seen Leary, as he had pawned some of his tools, and he wanted him to get them out again.

JOHN HILL re-examined. I know the prosecutor has authorized the prisoner to pawn his own apparel, but I cannot speak about these articles - when he could not get his pay he has made a piece of work, and the prosecutor has offered him his apparel to pledge.
NOT GUILTY .
NEW COURT. WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 24.
Second Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

2448.
EDWARD WILLIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of October , 3 lbs. of bacon, value 2s. , the goods of
John Lancaster
. - To which he pleaded

GUILTY . -
Whipped and Discharged.

2449.
CHARES JOHN FOX
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of September , 1 pair of spectacles, value 15s. , the goods of
David Child
.

DAVID CHILD
. I live in Berkley-court, Clerkenwell
. I met the prisoner at a public-house - I had never seen him before; we went home together, and had a game of cards; after he was gone my wife missed her spectacles; the prisoner called the next morning to borrow a pair of spectacles of our lodger, and then my wife asked for hers- he said he had not got them.

WILLIAM HENRY BAYFIELD
. I am a pawnbroker. I have this pair of spectacles, pawned by the prisoner on the 25th of September.

MARY CHILD
. I am the prosecutor's wife. The prisoner came to our house, and I missed my spectacles when he was gone - these are mine; I had had them ten years.

Prisoner's Defence. I acknowledge pawning the spectacles now produced; but these are my own, and I had had them ever since 1818 - they were made from a fine Brazilian pebble; the pawnbroker knows that I have pawned them before.
WILLIAM HENRY BAYFIELD. I have seen him with a pair - I do not know whether these were them or not.
NOT GUILTY .

2450.
DAVID GREEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of October
, 1 book, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
John Duncombe
.

JOHN DUNCOMBE. I live at St. Giles in the Fields
. On the 4th of October I lost a book from my window, which was open; the book stood about two feet in my shop - I do not know whether I was at home at the time; I went up to the Magistrate with another case, and he asked if I hadlost anything else, and he said he had another man in custody, from whom a duplicate had been taken, and it was for my book.

JAMES TRAIL
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a book, pawned on the 4th of October; I cannot say by whom - but this is the duplicate of it.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I and a friend were coming down Holborn, very much in liquor, he said, "I have a book in pawn, I bought it for a 1s.;" and I said I would bind it in sheep for him.
GUILTY . Aged 45.

2451.
DAVID GREEN
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of October
, 3 books, value 1s. 9d. , the goods of
John Aschon
.

BENJAMIN BRITTAN
. I am errand-boy to Mr. John Aschon; he lives in Chancery-lane
, and is a bookseller . On Saturday night, the 6th of October, I was sitting in the shop, and heard a noise as if some person was taking books; I looked, and saw three books were missing from one corner - I went out and saw the prisoner running; I called Stop thief! and charged him with taking the books; he said he had not got them - he had thrown them down an area; I stopped by him, and gave him in charge.
Prisoner. Q. Did you see me take the books? A. No; you were running off.

GEORGE BOULTON
(Police-constable F 100). I took the prisoner and found another book on him.

MARY ANN CLARK
. I live in Chancery-lane. I was going out, heard a cry of Stop, thief! and saw the prisoner running, and throw the books behind him - I heard the books fall; I took them up - there was nothing else.

Prisoner's Defence. I was walking down Chancery-lane very fast; I passed the shop, and the lad run out and said, "Give me them three books;" I said, "What books?" I kept on walking, and at the corner of Southamptonbuildings he gave me in charge; in going back he said,"These are the books;" I had never seen them.

GUILTY . Aged 45. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2452.
NEIL GOW
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of October , 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d., the goods of a man unknown, from his person .

PATRICK HAYES
. On the 13th of October I was in Tothill-street
, and saw a gentleman walking along; I saw the prisoner take the handkerchief out of his pocket - he then walked down Princes-street; I followed him, and saw him in the custody of the Policeman: the gentleman was gone when we came, and I charged the prisoner with taking it.

Cross-examined by MR. DONNE. Q. Where were you? A. At this end of Tothill-street, on the left hand side, and the prisoner was on the right - I only lost sight of him while he turned the corner to go into Princes-street.

WILLIAM WILLIAMS
(Police-constable B 68). In consequence of what Hayes told me I took the prisoner, and found this handkerchief in his right-hand trousers pocket; Hayes said it was the one he took - it is a good silk handkerchief.
Prisoner's Defence. I was going down the street - the Policeman beckoned to me, and said I had picked a gentleman's pocket - I said I had not; he said "Will you go to the station?" I said I would.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2453.
THOMAS HAYES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of June , 5 pairs of shoes, value 1l. 15s., the goods of
John Chard
, his master .

JOHN CHARD
. The prisoner was five years and a half in my employ; he lodged in the house, and never wanted work. I found these duplicates of the shoes on his seat; I suspected they were mine, and found they were - he was paid for what he did.

JOHN HAIGH
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a pair of shoes, which were pawned by the prisoner, I believe.

WILLIAM THOMAS
BARTON. I have three pairs of shoes, pawned I believe by the prisoner.

JOHN LOVICK
. I have a pair, pawned by the prisoner, to the best of my recollection.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 38. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2454.
GEORGIANA HARRISON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of October , 28 yards of printed cotton, value 7s. , the goods of
John Gower
.

JOSEPH DOLBY
. I am in the employ of Mr.
John Gower
. On the 8th of October, between eleven and twelve o'clock, Pierce told me we had lost something - I went in the direction pointed out, and in turning the corner of a street, we came up to the prisoner, who had been stopped with this piece of cotton, which I had placed there an hour before.

JOHN PIERCE
. I was passing the shop, and saw the prisoner take the cotton.
Prisoner. Q. Was it not you that told me to take it? A. No.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Confined Nine Months .

2465.
FRANCES JELLY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of October , 1 table-cloth, value 4s., and 1 sheet, value 4s. , the goods of
Elizabeth Serjeant
.

ELIZABETH SERJEANT
. I am single , and lodged in the prisoner's house for three weeks, in the front parlour. I went out on the 7th of October, and returned on the 10th - I had locked my door, and left the key with my sister; one night the prisoner's cap was found in my room - I missed my things on the 11th; I had strong suspicion of the prisoner, as she had been taken up the night before; I got a warrant, and found, in a pewter pint pot, on the mantelpiece, the duplicate of the sheet.

RICHARD STEPHEN WAYLETT
. This sheet was pawned at our house by the prisoner.

NICHOLAS SALMON
(Police-constable T 96). I searched the prisoner's premises, and found the duplicate in a pewter pot over the mantel-piece.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GEORGE WEBB
. I have a table-cloth; I do not know who pawned it - this is it.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 32.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Six Weeks .

2466.
HENRY JOHNSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of October , 2 books, value 4s. 6d. , the goods of
John Duncombe
.

JOHN DUNCOMBE
. About three o'clock in the afternoonof the 9th of October, I was at my desk, at the back of my shop, and saw the prisoner with another man - they shoved away some other persons, and then took two books; the prisoner put them under his arm, and walked off with them - I pursued, and took them from him.
The prisoner pleaded poverty.

GUILTY . Aged 31. -
Confined One Month .

2457.
SAMUEL KERRY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of October , 2 handkerchiefs, value 2s. , the goods of
George Taylor
.

JANE TAYLOR
. I am the wife of George Taylor; I am a laundress; I lost these two handkerchiefs from a line in Lucas-street, Salisbury-street
, where they hung to dry.

WILLIAM WILLSHER
. The prisoner was given into my charge by the prosecutrix's son; I took him, and found this one handkerchief on him.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 13. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2458.
MARIA KNIGHT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of October , 1 set of bed-furniture, value 5s.; 2 blankets, value 5s.; 2 pieces of carpet, value 5s.; 1 bolster, value 3s.; 2 pillows, value 2s.; 2 sheets, value 3s.; 1 looking-glass, value 1s.; 1 candlestick, value 1s., and 5 knives and forks, value 2s. , the goods of
Ann Moorwood
.

JOHN PRINCE
. I am a private gentleman. I was opposite Mr. Cassell's in Camden-town on the 13th of October, about half-past seven o'clock in the evening; I saw the prisoner carrying a basket, I followed her, and gave information to a Policeman, knowing her before - we then found the owner.

ROBERT BUGDEN
(Police-constable S 28). I followed the prisoner into Pratt-street; I took her with this basket; she told me where she lived, and we went there.

ANN MOORWOOD
. I am a widow . This basket contains two wine glasses, and two rummers of mine; I also lost two pieces of carpet, two blankets, a bolster, two sheets, and bed furniture - the pawnbroker has them; the prisoner lived in my house nearly three weeks; the whole of this property was let to her - she gave me no warning; I did not miss the property till she was taken.

JOHN WILLIAM
CASSELL. I am a pawnbroker; I have a sheet, two blankets, a pillow, and curtains, which were pawned by the prisoner.

WILLIAM JONES
. I am a pawnbroker. I was in my shop when the prisoner pawned this bolster, pillow, two pieces of carpet, looking-glass and decanter.

MRS. MOORWOOD. This is my property; she came to me as a married woman, and I let it her with the room; her husband who lived there with her, is a coach harness maker - he came home at night, and went out in the morning; have lost more articles.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that it was her intention to have replaced the property.

GUILTY . Aged 42. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2459.
BENJAMIN LAMB
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of September , 44 lbs. of flour, value 10s. 6d., the goods of
Robert Christopher Payne
, his master .

ROBERT CHRISTOPHER
PAYNE. I am a baker , at Hammersmith
; the prisoner was in my service about three months - I had no other person. On the 14th of September I missed about three pecks of flour out of a sack in my bake house - I have found it since; no one else could have taken it.

JOHN REYNOLDS
(Police-constable T 1.) On the morning of the 14th of September I was on duty, about a quarter-past six o'clock; Kelly came, and said he had found a bag, containing a large quantity of flour, in a ground near Mr. Payne's premises - I called Mr. Payne out, and asked if he had lost any flour; he went back, and found he had - I went into his premises, and found a place where a bag had been placed with flour, against a water-butt - I went down the yard, and saw a mark where a bag of flour had been drawn over a wall, nine feet high, and the same on the other side - when I was bringing the prisoner here, he asked me if Counsel would be of any service to him; he said, "I did not place the flour where it was found" - I said, "No, but there is no doubt you drew it over the wall;" he said, "I don't say but I did."

JAMES KELLY
(Police-constable T 113.) I found this flour, and gave information to Reynolds.
Prisoner. I am innocent - I had to take flour out of the sack to make my white bread.
R. C. PAYNE. The flour found in the bag corresponds in quality and quantity with what I lost.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Confined Six Months .

2460.
WILLIAM McCARTHY
and
JAMES RYAN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of October , 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
Frederick Goddard
, from his person .

AUGUSTUS FREDERICK GODDARD
. I belong to the Stock-exchange . On the 10th of October, about half-past four o'clock, I was in St. John's-lane, Clerkenwell
, walking steadily - I felt something at my pocket, and missed my handkerchief; I turned, and saw McCarthy with it - I took hold of him with one hand, and took the handkerchief with the other; the other prisoner, and two other boys, were close to me; Ryan ran off, but he was taken - the other two escaped.

WILLIAM HARRISON
. I am an officer. I took the prisoners, and have the handkerchief.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Ryan received a good character.

McCARTHY -
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Confined Six Months .

RYAN -
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Whipped and Discharged.

2461.
ANN MARTIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of September , 2 silver spoons, value 12s., the goods of
Philip Henry Shelton Colson
, her master .

PHILIP HENRY SHELTON COLSON. I am a surgeon , and live in Goswell-road
. The prisoner was in my service, as nurse , for four or five weeks; my wife came home on the Sunday night previous to the Saturday the prisoner was taken - she took off a brooch and laid it on the glass; that was missgin - we inquired, and could not find any thing of it; my wife then ordered her to look up the plate, and the two spoons were missing - I gave her in charge.
ROBERT CAMFIELD. I am a pawnbroker. I have two silver spoons, pawned by the prisoner's sister.

MARY SADLER
. I am sister-in-law to the prisoner; I pawned them, and did not know that I was doing wrong; for I knew they were meant to be redeemed - the prisoner gave them to me, and said she intended to redeem her gown.
Prisoner. What she says is true.

WILLIAM WINDER
(Police-constable G 52). I took the prisoner.
The prisoner pleaded poverty.
Property produced and sworn to.

GUILTY . Aged 32. -
Transported for 14 Years .

2462.
WILLIAM McDONALD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of September , 2 seals, value 7s.; 1 watch-key, value 6d.; 1 chain, value 18d.; 1 purse, value 2s.; 1 tooth-pick, value 2s., and 1 tinder-box, value 1s. , the goods of
William Cross
.

WILLIAM CROSS
. I am a waiter , and live in the Haymarket
. These things were lost from my bed-room; the prisoner was at work there as a bricklayer's labourer - I missed these and various other articles - suspicion fell on the prisoner, and he was taken.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Had you left the door open? A. The prisoner was at work in the room.

WILLIAM ROGERS
. I am a bricklayer. The prisoner was my labourer; the things were lost, and I had suspicion of him; we were at work up stairs at the top of the house.
Cross-examined. Q. How long has he worked for you? A. Only two days.

JOHN HILL
. I am a constable; I took the prisoner in Whitecross-street, on the 27th of September; I found this purse, two seals, a key, a German tinder-box, and a toothpick, on him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I am innocent of this - I picked it up outside the door; I exposed it publicly in the taproom, and the men advised me to keep it to see if it was advertised.

GUILTY . Aged 32. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2463.
WILLIAM NEST
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of September , 2 coats, value 30s. , the goods of
George Ford
.

GEORGE FORD. I am in the employ of Mr Henry Bruce, a window-glass merchant. One of these coats belongs to my fellow-servant , and the other to my master - they were in my master's gig, about a dozen yards from the door of the stable, in Savoy-street
- I just turned round and the coats were gone in a minute; I saw the prisoner at a little distance, rolling them up before him - I ran after him, and told him he had got a couple of coats he had just taken off the chaise; he said he had found them down below - they were left in the gig; I gave an alarm, and he was taken.

Cross-examined by MR. DONNE. Q. Neither of them belong to you? A. No - the prisoner was walking up the street; he said he was going to take them to the station - he made some resistance when he was taken.

GEORGE EDWARD GALLIVEY
. I was standing in my master's office, at the corner of Savoy-street; I saw the prisoner with the coats across his arm - Ford took them off his arm, and sent for an officer; the prisoner attempted to get off; I said he should not - he struck and kicked me very violently till the officer came up.(Property produced and sworn to).

Prisoner's Defence. I had occasion to go down the Dutch wharf - I saw the two coats lay, and took them up- I was going to the station, and the man came and said they were his master's; I gave them to him, without resistance.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2464.
SARAH PULLMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of October , 1 counterpane, value 2s.; 1 sheet, value 1s. 6d.; 1 tablecloth, value 6d.; 1 pillow-case, value 1d.; 1 hearth-rug, value 1s., and 1 blanket, value 3s. , the goods of
John Richard Short
.

ISABELLA SHORT
. I am the wife of John Richard Short. The prisoner lodged ten days in our house; she took the lodging weekly - she went away without notice, and left the key in the door, where we found it the next morning - her husband is a compositor , and did not live with her; she came to me as single; we missed the property stated on the Tuesday morning, and on the Friday she was taken; she owed me one week's rent.

JOHN OWEN
ELDRED. I am a pawnbroker. I have a counterpane, pawned for 2s., a sheet 1s. 6d., and a table-cloth and pillow-case for 1s.; I cannot say who by.
MRS. SHORT. This is my property; I lost this and a great deal more, which we have not found; it was all lent to the prisoner.
Prisoner. I know I pawned them, but with the intention of recovering them.

GUILTY . Aged 45. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2465.
MARY ANN THOMPSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of September , 10 shillings, the monies of
Francis Bensley
, from his person .

The
prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

2466.
ELIZABETH THOMPSON
and
ALICE BOREHAM
were indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of September , 1 gown, value 8s. , the goods of
Helina Wilson
.

HELINA WILSON. I live at Hackney-wick
. The prisoners lived in the house next to me; I go out ironing, and I take in washing at home; I do not know what the prisoners are; on the 14th of September, at six o'clock in the morning, I went out, and had left my gown on a clothes-horse in my room, on the ground floor.

REBECCA WILSON
. I was at home on the 14th of September; Thompson came in, and Boreham followed her; they asked me to let them boil some potatoes, and while the potatoes were on the fire, they both went out again; Thompson afterwards came and took the potatoes; I did not miss the gown till my mother came home.

JOHN SHORTHOUSE
(Police-constable N 200.) On the the 14th of September the prosecutor came and told me of this; I then took the prisoners into custody; Thompson denied all knowledge of it.

JOHN CHEESE
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a gown, pawned by Thompson; she was alone.
Thompon's Defence. I did not take the gown.
Boreham put in a written Defence, stating that the prosecutrix daughter had given her the gown to pledge, and she had given it to Thompson.

THOMPSON -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined Six Weeks .

BOREHAM
NOT GUILTY .

2467.
JOHN WILSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of October
, 1 handkerchief, value 6d., and 1 shilling , the property of
George William Barron
.

GEORGE WILLIAM BARRON
. I belong to the brig Eliza Ann . On the 17th of October she was laying at Woolwich - I was at a lodging house that night, as I had come up with our ships paper's; the next morning, when I awoke, I missed my handkerchief and 1s. out of my pocket - the prisoner had slept there, but he was gone; I had no more money in my pocket, all I had was gone - my handkerchief was found on his neck.

ROBERT EDWARDS
(Police-constable K 43). I took the prisoner about eleven o'clock that day; I charged him with robbing the sailor of the 1s., he told me I might go and find it - I found the handkerchief on his neck.
Prisoner. I put the handkerchief on in the dark; I am an entire stranger here.

GUILTY . Aged 40. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2468.
JOHN WILSON
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of October
, 1 pair of trousers, value 5s., and 1 sixpence , the property of
Richard Richardson
.

RICHARD RICHARDSON. I am a sailor . I slept in the same room and in the next bed to the prisoner; in the morning, after the prisoner was gone, I missed a pair of trousers and sixpence, which was in the pocket,

ROBERT EDWARDS
. I took the prisoner with these trousers on; I believe he had thrown his own old ones away.

GUILTY . Aged 40. -
Transported for 7 Years longer .
There were three other indictments against the prisoner.

2469.
WILLIAM WRIGHT
&
MARIA WRIGHT
were indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of October , 1 jacket, value 20s.; 1 waistcoat, value 10s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 14s.; 1 hat, value 12s., and 2 handkerchiefs, value 8s., the goods of
John Neal
, from his person .

JOHN NEAL. I am a sailor . I came to London by the Henry Brougham, from Palermo - I was discharged at the London-dock; I was paid off on the 15th of October - I was in Essex-street, Whitechapel
; I met two men - the male prisoner was not one; I had seen them before, but was not acquainted with them - I got into conversation with them; we went and had some beer - I was at that time sober; we then went to another house, which I thought was a public-house - I there saw the two prisoners; I am not certain whether there was any other woman there but Maria Wright; they sent for a pot of beer - I drank out of it; it was handed round - I do not know whether the others drank or not; I then felt myself all on a sudden very sleepy and drowsy - I could not keep my eyes open; I got up, and said I would go home by myself; I went out, leaving them all in the room - William Wright, and one of the two men who took me into the house, came and asked me to come back, and then
Maria Wright
came to me, and asked me to stop with her all night - I said no, I would not stop all night; they then would have me go back and finish the beer; I did not consent to go in, but they took me in, and set me down on the bed - I never felt myself so affected before as I was then; I soon fell fast asleep - I cannot tell how long I was asleep, but I think about an hour; I was shoved out of doors by the two prisoners - I had all my clothes on when I went to sleep; when they were shoving me out I had nothing on but my shirt, drawers, stockings, and shoes - I did not hear the prisoners say any thing when they were shoving me out; I sung out for help, went into the room again, and laid down on the bed, and said I would not leave the bed I had been robbed on, till I got my clothes.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What became of the other two men who took you in? A. I do not know, but one of them lent a hand to take me into the house again when I had left it - I had not got above three or four yards from the house when they took me back - I did not go in of my own accord the second time; I did not play at cards - I do not know who went for the beer; it was a small room - I did not notice whether there were any other persons there; two Policemen came to the house.

JOHN WILLIAM DENNIS
(Police-constable H 38). I was on duty in Essex-street about a quarter past nine o'clock- I saw the prosecutor there with only his drawers, shoes, stockings, and shirt on; he said he had been robbed in that house - I knocked at the door, and in a few minutes they opened it - both the prisoners were there; the prosecutor said the woman was one who had been in the room - he refused to go to the station till he got his clothes, but he afterwards went, and I took both the prisoners - I found none of the clothes; they denied that the prosecutor was there at all.

Cross-examined. Q. Was there another Policeman with you? A. Yes; but he went away, because the prosecutor would not substantiate the charge - he gave the woman in charge; but I took them both, for he said the man was there, and he had thrown him out of the room - he said two men had taken him into the room; he seemed in a very queer way; I do not know whether he was drunk, or any thing had been given to him - he was very drowsy.

William Wright
. I fetched the officer myself. -Witness. No; I was going up the street and saw the people standing and crying shame.
Maria Wright. The prosecutor never came to my door at all, till the officer came, and he knows he found my bed made, and no person had been there. -
