Witness. I do not know whether the bed was made or not, for as soon as the prosecutor got in, he went and laid down on it, and said he would not move till he had got his clothes.

W. WRIGHT -
GUILTY . Aged 20.

M. WRIGHT -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Life .

2470.
MARY ANN WATSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of October
, 1 tobacco pouch, value 6d.; 1 purse, value 6d.; 1 crown, and 1 half-crown, the property of
Peter Evans
, from his person ; and
RICHARD PARKINSON
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen .

PETER EVANS. I am a Norwegian sailor . On the 21st of October I was in Ratcliff-highway
, and saw Watson - she was at a door; I went in with her, and went to bed with her - I had paid her 3s.; she then went away - I then missed my tobacco-pouch, my purse, one crown, and one half-crown from my lefthand waistcoat pocket; I did not see Parkinson.

JOHN MELVILLE
(Police-constable K 63). I heard the prosecutor call Police! I went down; Watson was gone: I knew where she lived - I went and found her at her own house; I accused her of robbing the man- she said she had not taken any thing from him, and all the money she had in the world was one halfpenny - I asked her where her old man was, meaning Parkinson; I looked out of the window, and saw him outside - I got him in, searched, and found on him this little hammer, a crown-piece, and a half-crown: while I was doing that Watson ran off - I pursued and took her, and while I did that the serjeant searched Parkinson further, and found on him this purse and this pouch.
PETER EVANS. This is my purse.

Watson's Defence. I was sitting by my fire, he came to the door and asked if he might come in, and stay there; a woman came in - he sent for half a pint of gin, and a pot of porter; he said all he had was 7s. 6d., and a few halfpence - he gave me that; I took it to a woman to take care of for me; she gave it to Parkinson.
Parkinson's Defence. I received it from another woman to take care of.

WATSON -
GUILTY . Aged 41.

PARKINSON -
GUILTY . Aged 61.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

2471.
HENRY SHENLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August , 70 yards of straw plait, value 16s. , the goods of
John Leith
.

The same evidence was given as in the case of
Eliza Nelson
.
NOT GUILTY . (See page 224.)

2472.
EDWARD BIRD WEARING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of August , 1 book-case, value 4s.; 1 jar, value 6d.; 1 goblet, value 9d.; 2 dishes, value 9d.; 3 plates, value 9d., and 1 chain, value 6d. , the goods of
Joseph Bouchard
.
Mr. CHURCHILL, on behalf of the prosecution, delined offering any evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

2473.
ANN EDITH KERRIDGE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of October , 16 yards of ribbon, value 3s. , the goods of
John Udall
.
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

ROBERT UDALL
. I am superintendent of my father's business at Edmonton
- he is a draper - his name is John. On the evening of the 13th of October the prisoner came to his shop, and bought a pair of black worsted stockings; there was on the counter a drawer of black ribbons - she did not offer to buy any of them, but when she was gone I received information, and looked over the ribbons, and missed one, which had been safe ten minutes before - I knew the prisoner; she lived in the neighbourhood; I knew that when she left the shop; she had gone the contrary way to her own house, and she must return past the shop - I sent a witness to stop her; I went and asked her into the shop - I saw her drop this ribbon outside the door, on the pavement; I said she had better tell the truth.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What colour were the stockings? A. Black, and so was the ribbon; there were a good many other ribbons in the drawer, but no other of this width; I put the ribbon back into the drawer - I threw it in - my brother got the constable.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Did the ribbons and stockings stand so near to one another, that she could take one with the other? A. No; the stockings were in paper, and the ribbon in a drawer; there was no other piece of ribbon in the drawer that I could mistake for this; there is about sixteen yards of it.
COURT. Q. Did you sell her the stockings? A. Yes, and she had them in herlap when she came back.

ELIZABETH FRANKLIN
. I was in the prosecutor's employ, and was in his shop; the prisoner was at the counter- the stockings were at the end of the counter, in paper, and the ribbons were in a drawer a very little distance from the stockings - I saw the prisoner put her hand into the drawer, take something out, and put it into her lap; I not know what it was.

Cross-examined. Q. How near were the ribbons and stockings? A. A very little distance off - I knew where she lived; there was nothing to prevent her going straight home, but she went a contrary way, and passed our shop again.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Was there any thing that mixed the stockings with the ribbons, so that one could be taken with the other? A. No; the stockings were on her lefthand side, and the ribbons on the right.

JOHN HOCKLEY
. I live with the prosecutor. I remember the prisoner coming back; she hurled this ribbon from her apron on the pavement, and I took it up.
Cross-examined. Q. What do you mean by hurling it? A. She threw it on the pavement - my master was near her; it could not be seen by every body in the shop.
The prisoner received an excellent character.
GUILTY. Aged 18.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined One Month .
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

2474.
GEORGE MOODY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of October , 1 dial, value 4l., the goods of
Michael Smith Parnther
; and 1 umbrella, value 2s., the goods of
Edward Breese Robinson
.

THOMAS DEVEY
. I am constable of Aldgate ward. On Friday, the 12th of October, I observed the street door of Mr. Parnther's house, in Old London-street
, ajar; very great violence had been used to break it open; I found no one on the premises, but I found a candle and a match there - there was the appearance of a place where a dial had been; the mortar was quite fresh where it appeared to have been torn from the wall; I found a peg in the back office, on the floor, which appeared to fit a part of the dial-stand.

RICHARD BAYLIS
(Police-constable G 64.) At nine o'clock on the night of the 12th of October, I sawthe prisoner go into the door of a shop, in Portpool-lane, carrying this dial under his left arm, and this umbrella in his right hand - he went into Mrs. Brown's - he set the dial and umbrella down; Mr. Cole was in the shop; he came out, and then the prisoner said, "Mistress, I think I have something here that will suit you;" she said, "I don't want to have any thing to do with it;" I went into the shop, and said, "George, what are you going to do with the ticker?" he said, "I know nothing about it" - I called in my serjeant and brother officers; as we were taking him down Portpool-lane - he put his hand into his left-hand pocket, pulled out a phosphorusbox, and dropped it.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What was it you called that clock, a ticker? A. I meant this dial - I was close to the shop door, but his back was towards me- I waited to see if the woman bought them - we did not take her.

WILLIAM BARTON
. I am a Police-serjeant. Bailey's evidence is correct, but I did not hear the conversation- when I went in the prisoner had his back to the door, and the dial was on the counter.

JOHN HAVERSON
. I am clerk to Mr. Michael Smith Parnther. This dial is his property - I have the key; it was on his premises, No. 12, London-street - this umbrella is the property of Edward Breese Robinson, who is his clerk; I left the premises about six o'clock that evening, and shut the door, as usual - no one slept there: the next morning I missed the dial and umbrella - I had seen two or three fellows lurking about, and I believe the prisoner was one.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2475.
EDWARD MARTIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of October , 1 waistcoat, value 7s. , and 2 handkerchiefs, value 3s., the goods of
William Patrick
.

WILLIAM PATRICK. I lodge in Lower Gun-alley
. On the night of the 6th of October I went to bed, and left my waistcoat and two handkerchiefs in a chair by my bedside- the prisoner slept in the same room; I left him there when I got up next morning - I went up afterwards, and missed the things; the prisoner was then gone.

MARY PETRIE
. I am the wife of Robert Petrie; we live in Gun-alley. The prisoner came to lodge with us on the night of the 16th, and borrowed half a crown of me the next morning.

JAMES WILLIAM
BARGINALL. I am a waterman, and lodge in Gun-alley. The prisoner engaged me to go and fetch some things for him on the morning of the 17th; he gave me the slip, and I found him just getting into another man's boat - I pursued him, and took him to the Thames Police-office.

JAMES WHITE
. I am a Thames Police surveyor. I received the prisoner in charge, and found on him a waistcoat, two handkerchiefs, and 3s.
Prisoner's Defence. I was out of the room an hour before he missed the things - I bought them of a man in the street.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Confined Three Months .

2476.
JOHN SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of October , 2 jackets, value 1l. 18s.; 2 pairs of trousers, value 1l. 10s., and 4 shirts, value 6s. , the goods of
Henry Burton
.

HENRY BURTON. I am a mariner , and lodge at the Golden Anchor, in Leadenhall-street. I fell in with the prisoner; he had been an old shipmate of mine - he said he was in distress; I told him to call on me, and I would give him some employment - he did so, and I gave him a bag, containing jackets, trousers, shirts, and a variety of other things, to take to the rendezvous house, on Towerhill - I afterwards went there, but he and the things were not there; I received information, and went to the Angel, in Back-lane - I found him there, and part of my things were on his back; all he had on, except his braces, were mine - there are still three shirts, some jackets, and trousers missing.

JOHN EASTBROOK
(Police-constable K 25). I took the prisoner; he had these things on - he at first said he had sold the rest to a Jew, in a house; I asked him to tell me where the house was - he then said he sold them to a Jew in the street: I found 6s. 5d. on him, which he said was part of the money he had got for them.

GUILTY . Aged 28. -
Confined Three Months .

2477.
SAMUEL GEORGE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of October , 1 jacket, value 10s., and 1 pair of trousers, value 10s., the goods of
George Thomas Limington
: 1 pair of trousers, value 3s., the goods of
George Molland
; 1 pair of trousers, value 10s., and 1 jacket, value 7s., the goods of
Joseph Clare
.

GEORGE THOMAS LIMINGTON
. I live on board the Hyena
. On the 8th of October the prisoner came on board with a jacket, which he asked me to buy; I said it was too small for me - he then showed it to Molland, who also refused it; he then tied it up again - he went on shore with me and Molland; after I had dined I returned to the ship with Molland, I missed my jacket and trousers from my berth - these are them.

GEORGE SEAMAN
(Police-constable H 150). I apprehended the prisoner, and asked what he had done with the bundle; he said he should not tell me, for if he had six months in the House of Correction it would only serve to pass away the winter - I afterwards found in a boat belonging to a Dutch vessel, this bundle, which contains the property.

THOMAS WHITSITT
. I belong to the Silesia barque, which laid alongside the Hyena. I saw the prosecutor, Molland, and the prisoner go on shore; I afterwards saw the prisoner go on board the Hyena, and then come on shore with a large bundle in his hand; I do not know what were in it.
NOT GUILTY .

2478.
ANN WASHINGTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of October , 1 sheet, value 18d. , the goods of
Simon Knee
.

ANN KNEE
. I am the wife of
Simon Knee
. He let the prisoner a room in a house adjoining to ours, which we rent - she took it on the Monday evening, and we never saw her again till the Friday.

GEORGE WILLIAMS
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a sheet, which was pawned by the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GEORGE SPOTTISWOOD
PECK (Police-constable R 143.) I took the prisoner - she said she had pawned the sheet.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 29. -
Confined Seven Days .

2479.
JAMES HARDY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of October , 5 planks, value 16s., and 3 deal boards, value 12s. , the goods of
Edward Rayner
.

EDWARD RAYNER. I am the owner of a house at Oldford, in the parish of Stratford
; it was under repair, and in the charge of John Vines.

JOHN VINES
. I am a carpenter. I had the care of the house - the things were all safe there on the 14th of October, and the next morning I saw through my window some men putting some boards into a cart; I ran to the building, and saw the prisoner in the house, putting the boards and planks out - they belong to Mr. Rayner.

WILLIAM BALDWIN
(Police-constable K 201.) I took the prisoner on the spot, taking out the deals.
GUILTY. Aged 26.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Three Months .

2480.
CHARLES MITCHELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of September , 1 necklace, value 6s., the goods of
Charles Collins
, from the person of
Sophia Collins
; and that he had been before convicted of felony .

MARGARET RYAN
. I am in the service of Mr.
Charles Collins
- he lives in High-street, St. Giles'. In the afternoon of the 29th of September I left his house with his little girl Sophia , who is nine months old; she had a coral necklace on, with a gold snap - we went to Stacey-street, St. Giles'
; there was a crowd there , but I did not go into the crowd - the prisoner took the necklace off the child's neck ; I gave an alarm , and had him taken.

HENRY CURTIS
(Police-constable F 156). I took the prisoner in Stacey-street - I found nothing on him, but he had run some distance , and might have got rid of the necklace.

WILLIAM WETSLEY
(Police-constable E 154). I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got at Mr. Clark's office - I was present , and know he is the person .
The prisoner received a good character from his master, who engaged to employ him.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Confined Ten Days .

2481.
JAMES PARCELLS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of October , 3 boots , value 2s. 3d. , the goods of
James Border
.

JAMES BORDER
. I am a shoemaker , and live in Church-street, Bethnal-green
. On the 16th of October I looked through my window , and saw the prisoner with two other boy s - the prisoner was close to my window , he was pulling a boot through the window , and another lad was cutting the string of it - I followed the prisoner, and kept sight of him , and a man went for the officer ; the prisoner, who is a cripple , was taken, but he had nothing on him - this other boot , which is mine , was brought to my shop by a strange person ; the boot he took down was found about a yard from the spot .

SILVANAS GILL
(Police-constable H 55). I took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was coming past the shop, but did not notice the boots .

GUILTY . Aged 14. -
Confined Seven Days .

2482.
WILLIAM RAYNES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of October , 7 lbs. of horse-hair, value 5s. , the goods of
Benjamin Hewett
.

BENJAMIN HEWET
. I am master of the workhouse of St. Andrew , Holborn
- the prisoner was a pauper . On the 21st of October he had leave to go out ; I had some suspicion, and called him back - I found concealed under his clothes 7 lbs. of horse hair ; it exactly corresponds with what we had in the house - when we stopped him, he said , "I am done ."
Prisoner. Our provisions are very slack , and not sufficient for an aged man to do work .

JOHN WILLOUGHBY
(Police-constable G 49). I took the prisoner.

GUILTY . Aged 73. -
Confined Seven Days .
